defs.docs:
Iced is a cross-platform GUI library focused on simplicity and type-safety.
 Inspired by [Elm].

attributes.value: / Iced is a cross-platform GUI library focused on simplicity and type-safety.
/ * [Cross-platform support] (Windows, macOS, Linux, and the Web)
/ * First-class support for async actions (use futures!)
/   * A [renderer-agnostic native runtime] enabling integration with existing
/   * A [built-in renderer] supporting Vulkan, Metal, DX11, and DX12
/ Check out the [repository] and the [examples] for more details!
/ Inspired by [The Elm Architecture], Iced expects you to split user
/   * __Messages__ — user interactions or meaningful events that you care
/   * __View logic__ — a way to display your __state__ as widgets that
/   * __Update logic__ — a way to react to __messages__ and update your
/ We can build something to see how this works! Let's say we want a simple
/ counter that can be incremented and decremented using two buttons.
/ We start by modelling the __state__ of our application:
/     // The local state of the two buttons
/ Next, we need to define the possible user interactions of our counter:
/ the button presses. These interactions are our __messages__:
/ Now, let's show the actual counter by putting it all together in our
/ #     // The local state of the two buttons
/         // We use a column: a simple vertical layout
/                 // The increment button. We tell it to produce an
/                 // We show the value of the counter here
/                 // The decrement button. We tell it to produce a
/ Finally, we need to be able to react to any produced __messages__ and change
/ #     // The local state of the two buttons
/     pub fn update(&mut self, message: Message) {
/ And that's everything! We just wrote a whole user interface. Iced is now
/   1. Take the result of our __view logic__ and layout its widgets.
/   1. Process events from our system and produce __messages__ for our
/ The [`Application`] and [`Sandbox`] traits should get you started quickly,
/ streamlining all the process described above!

defs.name: Application
defs.docs: An interactive cross-platform application.

attributes.value: / This trait is the main entrypoint of Iced. Once implemented, you can run
/ your GUI application by simply calling [`run`](#method.run).
/ - On native platforms, it will run in its own window.
/ - On the web, it will take control of the `<title>` and the `<body>` of the
/ An [`Application`] can execute asynchronous actions by returning a
/ [`Command`](struct.Command.html) in some of its methods. If
/ you do not intend to perform any background work in your program, the
/ When using an [`Application`] with the `debug` feature enabled, a debug view
/ [The repository has a bunch of examples] that use the [`Application`] trait:
/ - [`clock`], an application that uses the [`Canvas`] widget to draw a clock
/ and its hands to display the current time.
/ - [`download_progress`], a basic application that asynchronously downloads
/ a dummy file of 100 MB and tracks the download progress.
/ - [`events`], a log of native events displayed using a conditional
/ - [`pokedex`], an application that displays a random Pokédex entry (sprite
/ - [`solar_system`], an animated solar system drawn using the [`Canvas`] widget
/ and showcasing how to compose different transforms.
/ - [`stopwatch`], a watch with start/stop and reset buttons showcasing how
/ [The repository has a bunch of examples]: https://github.com/hecrj/iced/tree/0.1/examples
/ If you just want to get started, here is a simple [`Application`] that
/ use iced::{executor, Application, Command, Element, Settings, Text};

defs.name: Executor
defs.docs: The [`Executor`] that will run commands and subscriptions.

attributes.value: / The [`Executor`] that will run commands and subscriptions.
/ The [default executor] can be a good starting point!

defs.name: Message
defs.docs: The type of __messages__ your [`Application`] will produce.

attributes.value: / The type of __messages__ your [`Application`] will produce.

defs.docs: The data needed to initialize your [`Application`].

attributes.value: / The data needed to initialize your [`Application`].

defs.name: new
defs.docs:
Initializes the [`Application`] with the flags provided to
 [`run`] as part of the [`Settings`].

attributes.value: / Initializes the [`Application`] with the flags provided to
/ Here is where you should return the initial state of your app.
/ Additionally, you can return a [`Command`](struct.Command.html) if you
/ need to perform some async action in the background on startup. This is
/ useful if you want to load state from a file, perform an initial HTTP

defs.name: title
defs.docs: Returns the current title of the [`Application`].

attributes.value: / Returns the current title of the [`Application`].
/ This title can be dynamic! The runtime will automatically update the
/ title of your application when necessary.

defs.name: update
defs.value: pub fn update(&mut Self, Self::Message) -> Command<Self::Message>
defs.docs: Handles a __message__ and updates the state of the [`Application`].

attributes.value: / Handles a __message__ and updates the state of the [`Application`].
/ This is where you define your __update logic__. All the __messages__,
/ produced by either user interactions or commands, will be handled by
/ Any [`Command`] returned will be executed immediately in the background.

defs.name: subscription
defs.docs:
Returns the event [`Subscription`] for the current state of the
 application.

attributes.value: / Returns the event [`Subscription`] for the current state of the
/ A [`Subscription`] will be kept alive as long as you keep returning it,
/ and the __messages__ produced will be handled by
/ By default, this method returns an empty [`Subscription`].

defs.name: view
defs.value: pub fn view(&mut Self) -> Element<, Self::Message>
defs.docs: Returns the widgets to display in the [`Application`].

attributes.value: / Returns the widgets to display in the [`Application`].
/ These widgets can produce __messages__ based on user interaction.

defs.name: mode
defs.docs: Returns the current [`Application`] mode.

attributes.value: / The runtime will automatically transition your application if a new mode
/ Currently, the mode only has an effect in native platforms.
/ By default, an application will run in windowed mode.

defs.name: run
defs.docs: Runs the [`Application`].

attributes.value: / On native platforms, this method will take control of the current thread
/ It should probably be that last thing you call in your `main` function.

defs.name: Element
defs.docs: A generic widget.

attributes.value: / This is an alias of an `iced_native` element with a default `Renderer`.

defs.name: Sandbox
defs.docs: A sandboxed [`Application`].

attributes.value: / If you are a just getting started with the library, this trait offers a
/ Unlike an [`Application`], a [`Sandbox`] cannot run any asynchronous
/ actions or be initialized with some external flags. However, both traits
/ are very similar and upgrading from a [`Sandbox`] is very straightforward.
/ Therefore, it is recommended to always start by implementing this trait and
/ [The repository has a bunch of examples] that use the [`Sandbox`] trait:
/ - [`bezier_tool`], a Paint-like tool for drawing Bézier curves using
/ - [`counter`], the classic counter example explained in [the overview].
/ - [`custom_widget`], a demonstration of how to build a custom widget that
/ - [`geometry`], a custom widget showcasing how to draw geometry with the
/ - [`pane_grid`], a grid of panes that can be split, resized, and
/ - [`progress_bar`], a simple progress bar that can be filled by using a
/ - [`styling`], an example showcasing custom styling with a light and dark
/ - [`svg`], an application that renders the [Ghostscript Tiger] by leveraging
/ - [`tour`], a simple UI tour that can run both on native platforms and the
/ [The repository has a bunch of examples]: https://github.com/hecrj/iced/tree/0.1/examples
/ If you just want to get started, here is a simple [`Sandbox`] that

defs.docs: Initializes the [`Sandbox`].

attributes.value: / Here is where you should return the initial state of your app.

defs.name: title
defs.docs: Returns the current title of the [`Sandbox`].

attributes.value: / Returns the current title of the [`Sandbox`].
/ This title can be dynamic! The runtime will automatically update the
/ title of your application when necessary.

defs.name: update
defs.docs: Handles a __message__ and updates the state of the [`Sandbox`].

attributes.value: / Handles a __message__ and updates the state of the [`Sandbox`].
/ This is where you define your __update logic__. All the __messages__,
/ produced by user interactions, will be handled by this method.

defs.name: view
defs.value: pub fn view(&mut Self) -> Element<, Self::Message>
defs.docs: Returns the widgets to display in the [`Sandbox`].

attributes.value: / Returns the widgets to display in the [`Sandbox`].
/ These widgets can produce __messages__ based on user interaction.

defs.name: run
defs.value: pub fn run(Settings<()>) where Self: 'static + Sized
defs.docs: Runs the [`Sandbox`].

attributes.value: / On native platforms, this method will take control of the current thread
/ It should probably be that last thing you call in your `main` function.

defs.docs: A default cross-platform executor.

attributes.value: / - On native platforms, it will use:

defs.docs:
If set to true, the renderer will try to perform antialiasing for some
 primitives.

defs.name: Column
defs.docs: A container that distributes its contents vertically.

attributes.value: / A container that distributes its contents vertically.
/ This is an alias of an `iced_native` column with a default `Renderer`.

defs.docs: A container that distributes its contents horizontally.

attributes.value: / A container that distributes its contents horizontally.
/ This is an alias of an `iced_native` row with a default `Renderer`.

defs.docs: Configure the window of your application in native platforms.

defs.docs: The application appears in its own window.

defs.docs: The application takes the whole screen of its current monitor.
